extracted_information: Apple's Human Interface Guidelines for motion and animation emphasize purposeful, fluid, and consistent design. Motion should convey status, provide feedback and instruction, and enrich the visual experience without overshadowing it. Gratuitous or excessive animation can distract or cause physical discomfort. It is critical to make motion optional and not use it as the sole means of communication, supplementing with haptics and audio for accessibility.

details: Add motion purposefully to support the experience, not overshadow it.
Avoid gratuitous or excessive animation as it can distract or cause discomfort.
Make motion optional: do not rely solely on motion for communication; supplement with haptics and audio.
Let people cancel motion: avoid making users wait for animations to complete.
Strive for realistic feedback motion that aligns with user gestures and expectations.
Aim for brevity and precision in feedback animations; they should feel lightweight and unobtrusive.
Generally avoid adding custom motion to frequently occurring UI interactions, as the system provides subtle animations.
Consider using animated SF Symbols (SF Symbols 5 or later) where appropriate.
Ensure game motion looks great by default on each supported platform (target 30 to 60 fps).
Allow customization of visual experience for performance or battery life (e.g., power modes).

features.details: No additional considerations beyond general guidelines.

details: Motion combines with depth to provide essential feedback for interactive elements.
Avoid displaying motion at the edges of a personâ€™s field of view to prevent distraction and discomfort; if necessary, match brightness levels.
Help people remain comfortable when moving large virtual objects by increasing translucency or lowering contrast.
Use fades to relocate objects when their movement does not communicate useful information.
Generally avoid letting people rotate a virtual world; use instantaneous directional changes during a quick fade-out instead.
Consider providing a stationary frame of reference to help users handle visual movement.
Avoid showing objects that oscillate in a sustained way, especially around 0.2 Hz; if necessary, keep amplitude low and content translucent.
SwiftUI provides a powerful way to add motion.
For animating layout/appearance changes or creating animated image sequences using WatchKit, refer to WKInterfaceImage.
